009
010package imagingbook.common.color.colorspace;
011
012import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.multiply;
013
014import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
015import imagingbook.common.math.PrintPrecision;
016
017/**
018 * <p>
019 * This class represents a linear chromatic adaptation transform,
020 * mapping XYZ color coordinates from a source white (reference) point
021 * to a target white point. 
022 * Both white points are passed to the constructor.
023 * The actual color mapping is done by method {@link #applyTo(float[])}.
024 * The underlying linear transformation is specified by a 3x3 matrix,
025 * which may be retrieved by {@link #getAdaptationMatrix()}).
026 * See the Section 14.6 of [1] for additional details and examples.
027 * </p>
028 * <p>
029 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; 
030 * An Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
031 * </p>
032 */
033public class BradfordAdaptation implements ChromaticAdaptation {
034        
035        // CAT forward transform matrix from XYZ to "virtual" RGB scaling coordinates
036        private static final double[][] MCAT = {
037            { 0.8951,  0.2664, -0.1614},
038            {-0.7502,  1.7135,  0.0367},
039            { 0.0389, -0.0685,  1.0296}};
040           
041        // CAT inverse transform matrix from "virtual" RGB scaling coordinates back to XYZ
042        private static final double[][] MCATi = Matrix.inverse(MCAT);     // we always invert for precision reasons
043//              {{ 0.9869929054667120, -0.1470542564209900, 0.1599626516637310}, 
044//               { 0.4323052697233940,  0.5183602715367770, 0.0492912282128560}, 
045//               {-0.0085286645751770,  0.0400428216540850, 0.9684866957875500}}
046        
047        // the complete color adaptation transformation matrix for transforming source XYZ to target XYZ,
048        // XYZ2 = Madapt * XYZ1, with
049        // Madapt = MCAT^-1 * DiagRGB * MCAT
050        private final double[][] Madapt;
051        private final double[][] Mdiag;
052        
053        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
054        
055        // static method for future caching of instances
056        public static BradfordAdaptation getInstance(double[] W1, double[] W2) {
057                return new BradfordAdaptation(W1, W2);
058        }
059        
060        // static method for future caching of instances
061                public static BradfordAdaptation getInstance(Illuminant illum1, Illuminant illum2) {
062                        return new BradfordAdaptation(illum1, illum2);
063                }
064        
065        /**
066         * Constructor (non-public) accepting two white points (XYZ-coordinates).
067         * 
068         * @param W1 source white point
069         * @param W2 target white point
070         */
071        private BradfordAdaptation(double[] W1, double[] W2) {
072                double[] rgb1 = multiply(MCAT, W1);
073                double[] rgb2 = multiply(MCAT, W2);
074                this.Mdiag = getRgbWhiteRatioMatrix(rgb1, rgb2);
075                this.Madapt = multiply(MCATi, multiply(Mdiag, MCAT));
076        }
077        
078        /**
079         * Constructor (non-public) accepting two {@link Illuminant} instances for
080         * specifying the source and target white points.
081         * 
082         * @param illum1 source illuminant
083         * @param illum2 target illuminant
084         */
085        private BradfordAdaptation(Illuminant illum1, Illuminant illum2) {
086                this(illum1.getXYZ(), illum2.getXYZ());
087        }
088        
089        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
090        
091        public static double[][] getMCAT() {
092                return MCAT;
093        }
094        
095        public static double[][] getMCATi() {
096                return MCATi;
097        }
098        
099        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
100        
101        // transformation of color coordinates
102        @Override
103        public float[] applyTo(float[] XYZA) {
104                // XYZB = Madapt . XYZA
105                float[] XYZB = new float[3];
106                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
107                        XYZB[i] = (float) (Madapt[i][0] * XYZA[0] + Madapt[i][1] * XYZA[1] + Madapt[i][2] * XYZA[2]);
108                }
109                return XYZB;
110        }
111        
112        @Override
113        public double[] applyTo(double[] XYZA) {
114                // XYZB = Madapt . XYZA
115                double[] XYZB = new double[3];
116                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
117                        XYZB[i] = Madapt[i][0] * XYZA[0] + Madapt[i][1] * XYZA[1] + Madapt[i][2] * XYZA[2];
118                }
119                return XYZB;
120        }
121        
122        /**
123         * Returns the composite color adaptation transformation matrix.
124         * @return the color adaptation transformation matrix
125         */
126        public double[][] getAdaptationMatrix() {
127                return this.Madapt;
128        }
129        
130
131        // Creates a diagonal matrix with the ratios of the rgb components
132        // obtained by transforming the two white points
133        private static double[][] getRgbWhiteRatioMatrix(double[] rgbA, double[] rgbB) {
134                if (rgbA.length != rgbB.length) {
135                        throw new IllegalArgumentException();
136                }
137                final int n = rgbA.length;
138                double[][] M = new double[n][n];
139                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
140                        M[i][i] = rgbB[i] / rgbA[i];
141                }
142                return M;
143        }
144        
145        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
146        
147        public static void main(String[] args) {
148                PrintPrecision.set(8);
149                
150                System.out.println("W1 (D65) = " + Matrix.toString(StandardIlluminant.D65.getXYZ()));
151                System.out.println("W2 (D50) = " + Matrix.toString(StandardIlluminant.D50.getXYZ()));
152                
153                BradfordAdaptation adapt = new BradfordAdaptation(StandardIlluminant.D65, StandardIlluminant.D50);      // adapts from D65 -> D50
154                
155                
156                System.out.println("Mdiag = \n" + Matrix.toString(adapt.Mdiag));
157                
158                System.out.println("Madapt = \n" + Matrix.toString(adapt.getAdaptationMatrix()));
159                System.out.println();
160                
161                
162                
163//              
164//              ColorSpace cs = sRgb65ColorSpace.getInstance();
165//              float[] red = {1, 0, 0};
166//              float[] grn = {0, 1, 0};
167//              float[] blu = {0, 0, 1};
168//              
169//              float[] rgb1 = blu;
170//              
171//              System.out.println("rgb1 = " + Matrix.toString(rgb1));
172//              float[] XYZ65 = cs.toCIEXYZ(rgb1);
173//              System.out.println("XYZ65 = " + Matrix.toString(XYZ65));
174//              
175//              double[] xy65 = CieUtil.XYZToXy(Matrix.toDouble(XYZ65));
176//              System.out.println("xy65 = " + Matrix.toString(xy65));
177//              
178//              float[] XYZ50 = adapt.applyTo(XYZ65);
179//              System.out.println("XYZ50 = " + Matrix.toString(XYZ50));
180//              
181//              double[] xy50 = CieUtil.XYZToXy(Matrix.toDouble(XYZ50));
182//              System.out.println("xy50 = " + Matrix.toString(xy50));
183//              
184//              float[] rgb2 = cs.fromCIEXYZ(XYZ65);
185//              System.out.println("rgb2 = " + Matrix.toString(rgb2));
186                
187        }
188        
189        
190}
